Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Low Cost, High Performance Ultrathin GaAs Solar Cells for Terrestrial Photovoltaics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract:
Low Cost, High Performance Ultrathin Gallium Arsenide Solar Cells for Terrestrial Photovoltaics

Nontechnical:
Despite their impressive performance reaching near the theoretical limit, the practical application of gallium arsenide solar cells in on-earth applications remains a formidable challenge largely due to the excessively high cost of growing device-quality epitaxial materials. The research outlined in this proposal aims to address the future energy demand of global society by developing a practical solution that can balance the high performance of gallium arsenide solar cells with their production cost, and therefore enable their large-scale deployment in terrestrial photovoltaics. The highly multidisciplinary themes of the proposed research will be intimately integrated with comprehensive teaching and outreach efforts. PI Yoon will work with the Center for Engineering Diversity at the University of Southern California to establish laboratory internship opportunities for educationally-disadvantaged middle and high school students in the inner city of Los Angeles. Co-PI Lee will partner with Yale Science Outreach on two particular programs: Science on Saturdays for families and the general public and the Pathways to Science program for middle and high school students. Training both undergraduate and graduate student researchers will be a primary educational goal, where the PIs will continue to support and encourage broadening participation of female students and students from underrepresented groups.

Technical:
The goal of this collaborative research is to demonstrate high performance, cost-competitive GaAs solar cells for their large-scale deployment in terrestrial photovoltaics. To achieve this goal, we will develop novel strategies of materials growth and device fabrication exploiting (1) an ultrathin device platform that enables efficient use of expensive source materials, (2) multilayer epitaxial growth that can significantly reduce the cost of epitaxial materials, (3) bifacial nanophotonic light manipulation that can enhance the absorption, (4) high yield printing techniques that permits large-area distribution over low cost substrates. Specifically, Task 1 will explore the growth of multiple device stacks of ultrathin GaAs solar cells in molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) targeting uniform materials properties and device performance of multilayer-grown epitaxial stacks. Task 2 will seek to establish fundamental understanding and optimization of the epitaxial design for ultrathin GaAs solar cells to enhance the carrier collection and maximize the effectiveness of light trapping. Task 3 will focus on developing integrated schemes of bifacial photon management for light trapping and photon recycling. Successful completion of the proposed research will lead to the development of high performance, economically viable GaAs solar cells for terrestrial applications and also strengthen fundamental understanding of: materials behaviors and dopant diffusion in MBE-grown multilayer epitaxial assemblies; optimized layer structures of ultrathin GaAs solar cells for the most efficient photovoltaic energy conversion; multifunctional optical designs for maximized light absorption in the optically thin absorber.

POR.DRECONTENT:
III-V solar cells made of materials such as gallium arsenide (GaAs) have achieved the highest reported solar cell efficiencies (29.1%), well above the efficiency limit for silicon solar cells (27%), the current dominant technology. Despite their efficiency advantages, III-V solar cells are more than 10x more expensive than their silicon counterparts, and hence they are only commercially used in satellites. One of the reasons that III-V solar cells are so expensive is the materials cost. To start, manufacturers must purchase slices of single-crystal GaAs (i.e. GaAs wafers), which are far more expensive than silicon wafers. To make matters worse, the solar cell layers then have to be deposited on top of the GaAs wafers using highly purified sources in expensive crystal growth equipment through a process known as epitaxy; the expensive GaAs wafer is then relegated to being little more than a handling carrier for the solar cell sitting on top. In contrast for silicon, the wafer is the solar cell and no additional crystal growth is required after the wafer is manufactured.

This project aimed to set the stage for dramatic cost reductions in GaAs solar cells by reducing both the cost of the starting wafers and the cost of crystal growth. Essentially, we start with a GaAs wafer and then, instead of growing one GaAs solar cell on top, we grow three or more solar cells on top. The multiple solar cells can then be controllably separated from one another (and from the wafer) using a chemical process termed ?epitaxial lift-off? and placed onto less expensive substrates through a process termed ?transfer printing.? In this way, one expensive GaAs wafer becomes the seed for multiple solar cells, instead of the usual one solar cell. In order to save on the cost of growth, we designed each GaAs solar cell to be 10x thinner than a normal GaAs solar cell, which is to say 100x thinner than a sheet of paper. In addition to saving on materials costs, such thin solar cells could one day be wrapped around buildings, automobiles, and other curved surfaces due to their high flexibility. However, with the flexibility comes a penalty in the form of increased transparency to light and hence decreased efficiency. Therefore, this project had two major goals- to understand how to design and grow ultra-thin multi-layer solar cells and how to process these solar cells in a way that sunlight becomes ?trapped? inside of them.

We ultimately demonstrated 10 solar cells grown on top of a single GaAs wafer, which was unprecedented. Moreover, we were able to show an efficiency as high as 17.2% with nanophotonic light trapping, as well as a computed roadmap to 25% efficiency. One challenge that arose was undesired intermixing of trace chemical elements called ?dopants? within the solar cells during the high-temperature crystal growth process, which led to performance variation among the many solar cells in the stack. By the end of the project, we succeeded in eliminating this variation by using dopant atoms that do not diffuse during crystal growth; once they are incorporated into the crystal, they are effectively frozen in place. By so doing, we showed that highly uniform cell performance could be maintained, paving the way for future manufacturability. The growth techniques, processing methods, and light trapping structures that were developed in this project could have important uses in applications ranging from wearable electronics to sensors for the internet-of-things. The technical accomplishments of this project were published as articles in high-visibility journals.

In addition to these technical achievements, this program funded the PhD research of a graduate student who will defend his thesis in 2020. The student benefited tremendously from NSF support and won a highly competitive best poster prize at a major international conference. The materials and devices generated in this research were also used to train undergraduate interns in the lab, while the results were discussed in undergraduate courses.
